awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A geomagnetic intensity time series from the Proterozoic Laramie anorthosite
awd_abstract_narration:
The research project will document variations of the Earth's magnetic field strength for the period from approximately 1440 to 1380 million years ago to test models of geomagnetic field formation and the thermal evolution of the Earth. The Earth's magnetic field protects the Earth's surface from harmful cosmic radiation and potential interruptions of communication systems and electrical grids. To predict the stability and strength of the Earth's magnetic field, it is essential to understand how the field formed and what processes control its strength. It has been argued that the nucleation of the solid inner core led to a prominent and robust increase in geomagnetic strength, but the timing of inner core formation is in some dispute. Sparse and possibly biased data on the intensity of the magnetic field have been used to argue for inner core formation at about 1400 million years ago, but recent estimates of core thermal conductivity suggest that inner core growth may have begun only in the latest Precambrian, approximately 600 million years ago. The research in this project will provide high-quality, well-dated estimates of the ancient magnetic field over a critical time period in the evolution of Earth's magnetic field.

Integrated magnetic, petrologic and thermochronologic data from the well-dated 1430 million year old Laramie anorthosite complex will be used to construct a time series of geomagnetic intensity (and directional) variations. Samples will be collected from a series of eight drill cores, each about 50m in length, and complementary surface coring systematically away from the preserved cooling margin of the intrusion. The paleointensity study will focus on small subsamples designed to isolate the high-stability remanence carried by magnetite within plagioclase crystals. The precise cooling history will be determined from U-Pb radioisotopic dates of the mineral apatite, which has a thermal closure temperature of approximately 450°C, close to the minimum temperatures of remanence acquisition. The pristine cores will be dual purposed as they will also be used to investigate primary igneous petro-fabrics and the processes by which igneous foliations and any lineations have been produced, thereby deepening our understanding of the crystallization processes of igneous bodies. The project will train several undergraduate students, form the basis for one PhD dissertation, and strengthen collaboration among scientists at two institutes, the University of California San Diego (Scripps Institution of Oceanography) and the University of Wyoming (Department of Geology and Geophysics).

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Long term variations of geomagnetic field intensity (and direction) are some of the few sources of information on the evolution of our planet’s deep structure in the distant past. In particular, models indicate that Earth’s magnetic field may have transitioned from a relatively weak to a stronger state when the planet developed a the solid inner core. This change in Earth’s magnetic field should be identifiable in records of the intensity and direction of Earth’s magnetic field preserved in rocks of the appropriate age. Indeed, sparse data on the intensity of the magnetic field have been used to argue for inner core formation at about 1400 million years ago. These estimates of magnetic field intensity are sparse because they are challenging to obtain. Many rocks do not contain the fine-grained magnetic minerals needed to reliably preserve intensity information and additionally these minerals may alter during the repeated laboratory heatings needed to estimate the ancient field intensity. Large igneous intrusions cool slowly at depth and may contain suitable rocks for magnetic experiments, and so should preserve an extended record of magnetic field variations.

 

This project was designed to document variations in Earth's magnetic field strength near the proposed age of inner core formation. To this end, we systematically sampled the 1435-million-year-old Laramie Anorthosite (WY) at about 60 locations spanning about 1500m from near the (relatively quickly-cooled) margin of the intrusion towards its center and at a range of scales from centimeters to kilometers. Many of these rocks are likely to be reliable recorders of Earth’s ancient magnetic field at the time of their formation: most contain large silicate crystals that encapsulate fine-grained, elongate magnetite grains, which can preserve magnetic records over geologic time and are resistant to change in laboratory experiments. Using these samples, we determined that Earth’s magnetic field near 1400 million years ago likely varied over a range of intensities (from <20 to >80 mT) similar to fluctuations in more recent time periods. We interpret trends in geomagnetic records over spatial scales of ~100m to reflect trends through time in geomagnetic intensity.

 

Additionally, the systematic sampling along with new (U-Pb) isotopic dates determined as part of this project improved our understanding of the timing of variations in Earth’s magnetic field around the proposed age of inner core formation. The ages, which correspond closely to the timing and temperature range at which the rocks were magnetized, suggest that cooling from ~800°C to ~450°C could have been nearly instantaneous. However, the error limits on the dates also are compatible with slower cooling in the intrusion interior over this temperature range by as much as three million years. Coupled with the patterns we have documented in the geomagnetic records from the interior to the exterior of the intrusion, these ages suggest that our geomagnetic intensity estimates represent variation in Earth’s magnetic field through time over a relatively short interval in the Proterozoic.

 

The similarity in both intensity and variations of the Earth's magnetic field between present day and 1435 million years ago strengthen confidence in the use of paleomagnetic orientations in defining Precambrian continental associations and reconstructions.  The resulting pre-Pangea supercontinent reconstructions and movements establish strong correlations between tectonics and paleoclimate and inform models for mineralization timing and style.  These in term improve mineral exploration methods and success.
